user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_DeleteAllObjects:
```c
void OS_DeleteAllObjects(void)
{
    uint32 ObjectCount;
    uint32 TryCount;

    /*
     * Note - this is done in a loop because some objects depend on other objects
     * and you will not be able to delete the object until the ref count becomes zero.
     */
    TryCount = 0;
    while (true)
    {
        ObjectCount = 0;
        ++TryCount;

        /* Delete timers and tasks first, as they could be actively using other object types  */
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);

        /* Then try to delete all other remaining objects of any type */
        OS_ForEachObject(OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);

        if (ObjectCount == 0 || TryCount > 4)
        {
            break;
        }
        OS_TaskDelay(5);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_DeleteAllObjects:
typedef uint32_t  uint32
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_ForEachObject(OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in this fragment as written: ObjectCount is intended to be modified by the callback (OS_CleanUpObject) so passing &ObjectCount as a non-const pointer is appropriate. A violation would occur if the API and callback do not modify the pointed-to data but nonetheless accept a non-const pointer (for example if OS_ForEachObject/OS_CleanUpObject take a void * and only read the data) — in that case the parameter should be const-qualified (const void *) and the code should pass a pointer-to-const or otherwise use const-correct signatures.
